image.altText: two cranes repairing a wharf.

props.synopsis: The GEMCO manganese mine has resumed exports for the first time since severe cyclone damage to its Groote Eylandt wharf brought operations to a halt last year.

title.children: Major NT mine resumes exports after 14-month halt from cyclone damage

image.altText: A white woman, short blonde hair, wearing glasses, white blazer and blue top. Standing in front of blurred green background

props.synopsis: The NT parliament has passed new laws to restore mandatory minimum sentencing for some domestic violence order breaches, despite widespread disapproval from women's legal services.

title.children: Mandatory sentencing reinstated for some DVO breaches in NT

image.altText: A police man smiling surrounded by dry bushland.

props.synopsis: A coronial inquest into the suicide of Northern Territory Constable Michael Deutrom is set to examine the challenges faced by police officers and whether more can be done to support those on the frontline.

title.children: Inquest to examine NT police officer's suicide after 23 years on frontline

image.altText: Close-up shot of man wearing a suit.

props.synopsis: The NT government has faced criticism over its move to hand a former gas executive "extraordinary powers" to green-light private development, without publicly recruiting for the "highly-paid" position.

title.children: Closed recruitment of ex-gas boss to 'extraordinary' public job criticised

image.altText: Young girl Camille in bed showing her arms which have wound plasters on her arms.

props.synopsis: Experts say it is the worst year for the soil-born disease in Queensland in around three decades. Meet those who've survived the deadly disease and learn more about what to look out for.

title.children: Three months and 50 tests later, 11yo discovers what made her sick 'by chance'

image.altText: Tony Abbott

props.synopsis: Former prime minister Tony Abbott says he hopes the Coalition can re-form "as soon as possible". Follow live.

title.children: Tony Abbott says he 'deeply regrets' Coalition split

image.altText: A digital drawing of Erin Patterson wearing a pink shirt

props.synopsis: The Leongatha mother is charged with murdering three relatives by serving them a beef Wellington meal that contained poisonous death cap mushrooms. Follow the trial live.

title.children: Computer expert gives evidence at Erin Patterson's murder trial

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Records shown to court show death cap mushroom page
What police found on computer in Erin Patterson's home
Police search for 'death cap' on computer in Erin Patterson's house

image.altText: Empty 'next service' screens at Parramatta Station amid massive train delays

props.synopsis: Sydney Trains are working to get six tracks operational on the network after a heavy rail collided with overhead wires near Strathfield on Tuesday afternoon. Follow live.

title.children: 'Challenging afternoon' ahead for Sydney trains despite repairs

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Where to stay up-to-date on trips
'Cancelled': Transport apps leave commuters in the dark still
Cab alternatives too expensive, says commuter

image.altText: Poster saying 'Wanted by the FBI' with name and mugshot image of Australian man Geoffrey John Busch

props.synopsis: Geoffrey John Busch is wanted over an investment scam in Florida in the early 2000s and just months after a renewed FBI effort to track him down, the ABC found him living in Sydney's southern suburbs.

title.children: Man wanted by FBI found 'living in a family environment' in Sydney

image.altText: A teenage girl with long, dark hair.

props.synopsis: Pheobe Bishop went missing from Bundaberg last week. Police have now declared a seized vehicle and a house crime scenes as they continue to investigate her disappearance.

title.children: Crime scenes declared as police search for missing 17-year-old girl

image.altText: Will Goodge raises his arms with a banner

props.synopsis: British runner William Goodge broke the record for completing a trans-Australia run by a whopping four days — but there are a handful of people in ultra-running who have questions.

title.children: This man took 4 days off the trans-Australia run record, but some have questions

image.altText: People walking past a Westpac sign.

props.synopsis: Westpac hasn't put a number on job cuts, after reports 1,500 could go. The Australian share market is higher following the Reserve Bank's decision to slash interest rates to a two-year low. Follow live.

title.children: 'Deeply disappointing': Union calls on Westpac to shelve job cut plans

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Has your lender passed on the rate cut?
Mayne Pharma plunges on potential deal collapse with Cosette

image.altText: Large billboard of man with politcal slogans

props.synopsis: First Nations leaders have issued an extraordinary statement, saying they fear the Queensland government is trying to "destroy" Indigenous communities by forcibly transferring children from their families.

title.children: Fears Queensland's laws 'intend to destroy' First Nations families: leaders

image.altText: A young woman holding out bowls of food to her four children next to some camps at a refugee camp.

props.synopsis: Humanitarian organisations warn current aid levels are not enough to tackle the hunger crisis gripping Gaza, as the British government suspends trade talks with Israel over its expanded military offensive in the strip.

title.children: UN issues warning as Gazan babies face food shortages

image.altText: Anthony Albanese Xi Jinping composite

props.synopsis: The trip follows a warm letter of congratulations from China's leader following Anthony Albanese's election win.

title.children: Second China visit for Albanese as Xi seeks closer Australia ties

image.altText: Visitors walk towards Dingley Dell, a white heritage cottage surrounded by greenery, with signage visible in the foreground

props.synopsis: A former dot-com millionaire's plan to install glamping tents at Adam Lindsay Gordon's cottage is opposed by fans of the 19th-century poet.

title.children: Fans of 19th-century poet fight former tech billionaire's glamping bid

image.altText: Tomatoes hanging on vines at a tomato farm.

props.synopsis: A destructive exotic tomato plant disease that had a major impact in South Australia and Victoria has been linked to New South Wales for the first time.

title.children: Devastating tomato plant virus detection linked to NSW nursery

image.altText: A sign that says "Karumba" in an outback area.

props.synopsis: The 56-year-old is accused of offences against nine people, including children, that allegedly occurred over a 20-year period.

title.children: Outback Queenslander charged with 40 historical sex offences

image.altText: Reevce1

props.synopsis: Reece Walsh says a video of him punching a friend in the face while wearing a boxing glove is "not a good look".

title.children: Broncos star explains why he punched friend in face for social media

image.altText: an outside view of a row of houses

props.synopsis: Many hoped that interest rate cuts could make housing more affordable. But cheaper money for housing, amid a market with high demand and low supply, will keep fuelling property prices.

title.children: 'Impossibly unaffordable': Why property prices in Australia will keep rising

image.altText: A group of teenagers sit together with their backs turned at a high school

props.synopsis: Teenagers and young people are facing new threats that could see their health and wellbeing go backwards, a new Lancet report warns.

title.children: Report reveals new health risks faced by first digital native generation

image.altText: Tottenham Hotspur manager Ange Postecoglou holding his chin. thinking, on a football pitch touchline

props.synopsis: Ange Postecoglou says he has no concerns about his future as Tottenham manager, arguing all his focus is on his side's Europa League final against Manchester United.

title.children: 'I'm not a clown': Defiant Postecoglou puts Spurs first ahead of Europa League final

image.altText: A black and white photo with four men, three on a large felled jarrah tree

props.synopsis: Native timber logging is now banned in Western Australia, but old stories and photos of the pioneering workers and their families are recorded in historical archives.

title.children: Back-breaking work of jarrah axemen, who severed fingers for extra pay

image.altText: Roia Atmar holds a framed photo of her three  young children

props.synopsis: Mother-of-four Roia Atmar says that her husband burned her in a bid to disfigure her so "nobody else would look at me". Researchers say domestic burns violence cases like hers are often under-reported for reasons including fear and shame.

title.children: Domestic violence burns cases 'reasonably common' researchers say

image.altText: a sign on the side of a rugby league pitch calling for good behaviour

props.synopsis: Players and parents are being warned action will be taken if referees continue to face threats of violence, as one league reveals a junior referee had to be escorted to their car due to threatening behaviour.

title.children: ‘Appalling’ behaviour derails junior rugby league season

image.altText: a childs hand and mothers hands playing with lego blocks

props.synopsis: The NSW government is investing millions into family preservation services to reduce crisis management and keep kids out of foster homes. A mother explains how it worked for her family.

title.children: Family preservation or child protection? For Tara, the answer is clear

image.altText: Daniel Mookhey

props.synopsis: With dissent mounting, tensions are set to escalate within caucus and close stakeholders, including the unions.

title.children: NSW workers comp changes dubbed a 'bandaid solution'

image.altText: man in country h at watching opera, dinosaur statue to the right

props.synopsis: They are two music genres people love to hate — opera and country. But somewhere under a vast outback sky they find a shared audience.

title.children: Two music genres people 'love to hate' find success in the outback

image.altText: A large metal silo on a farm at sunset. One side has been replaced with glass windows and inside is accommodation.

props.synopsis: Old silos that were once used for storing food are undergoing glamorous transformations to become luxury accommodation, providing new income streams for farmers.

title.children: It was not cheap, but these old silos have been transformed into luxury

image.altText: women helping

props.synopsis: A group of women in the outback are meeting up over a cuppa to learn how to sew and speak English.

title.children: Outback sewing classes help migrants learn English and find friendship

image.altText: A woman runs along the beach towards the camera with hills and water in the background.

props.synopsis: An education worker and advocate in her hometown of Karratha, Chanti McHenry is one of 12 competitors from across Australia training with the Indigenous Marathon Project.

title.children: Years of effort sees WA woman locked in for New York Marathon

image.altText: A 1930s Sepia photo of six men in civilian clothes standing on the deck of a ship.

props.synopsis: When one side of the Spanish Civil War asked the world for help, a small band of Australian men and women answered the call.

title.children: Australia told these people not to go to war. They went anyway

image.altText: A man in a jacket and black shirt looks at the camera.

props.synopsis: A few years on from The Idol, The Weeknd's newest project seems hell-bent on ruining whatever's left of his audience goodwill. But it's also incredibly compelling.

title.children: The Weeknd's new film is sexist, vain and completely compelling
